title: Holt Heath National Nature Reserve Walking Route

images.title: John Smitten [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Holt Heath National Nature Reserve in late summer. View looking north from the Ferndown, Stour and Forest Trail.

images.title: Nigel Mykura [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View across the north side of the heath from close to the road from Mannington to Holt. This is one of the largest tracts of heathland left in Dorset, now owned by the national Trust. Only 15 per cent of the original acreage of this rare habitat now remains in Dorset. Originally the local commoners' practice of grazing stock and gathering firewood kept the heath in this condition. Nowadays this has to be done artificially to preserve the heath and it rare flora and fauna. Thomas Hardy made this kind of heathland famous in his books such as Return of the Native.

images.title: Pond,  Near Summerlug Hill, Holt Heath by Lorraine and Keith Bowdler, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Pond, Near Summerlug Hill

images.title: Tumulus, Summerlug Hill, Holt Heath by Lorraine and Keith Bowdler, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Tumulus and yellow gorse, Summerlug Hill

images.title: Lorraine and Keith Bowdler / Bull Barrow Tumulus
images.caption: Bull Barrow Tumulus SW of Crooked Withies. The tumulus almost merges into the hillside, although it is easier to see now they have cut down the gorse and other bushes that grew on it.

images.title: Lorraine and Keith Bowdler / Cocks' Moor Pond
images.caption: Cocks' Moor Pond

images.title: Holt Heath, disused pit by Mike Faherty, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Holt Heath, disused pit

images.title: White Sheet Plantation, clear fell by Mike Faherty, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: White Sheet Plantation, clear fell

description: Enjoy a walk through beautiful Dorset heathland in this delightful National Nature Reserve near Wimborne Minster. There are miles of good walking tracks taking you through over 1000 acres of woodland and heathland. In the summer the purple heather and gorse are really beautiful. The area is also fantastic for wildlife - look out for New Forest Ponies, Dartford warbler, Curlews, various reptiles and a variety of butterflies. This circular walk starts at the Whitesheet car park and follows footpaths across the heath to Cock's Moor Pond and Newman's Lane. You then pick up the Ferndown, Stour and Forest Trail to take you back to the car park through peaceful woodland. If you'd like to continue your walking in the area then you could pick up the Castleman Trailway and head into the nearby Ferndown Forest for more peaceful woodland trails.
